'''Jim Jackson''' ([[circa|c]].1884 - 1937) was an [[African American]] [[blues]] and [[hokum]] [[singer]], [[songster]] and [[guitarist]], whose [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] in the late 1920s were  popular and influential on later [[musician|artists]].

==Career==
Jackson was born in [[Hernando, Mississippi|Hernando]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]],<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p382/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography - accessed January 2008]</ref> and was raised on a farm, where he learned to play guitar.  Around 1905 he started working as a singer, dancer, and musician in [[medicine show]]s, playing dances and parties often with other local [[musician]]s such as [[Gus Cannon]], [[Frank Stokes (musician)|Frank Stokes]] and [[Robert Wilkins]].<ref name="amg"/> He soon began travelling with the [[Rabbit Foot Minstrels]], featuring [[Ma Rainey]] and [[Bessie Smith]], and other [[minstrel show]]s.  

He also played clubs on [[Beale Street]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]]. His popularity and proficiency secured him a residency at Memphis's prestigious [[Peabody Hotel]] in 1919.  Like [[Lead Belly]], Jackson knew hundreds of songs including blues, ballads, vaudeville numbers, and traditional tunes, and became a popular attraction. 

In 1927, talent scout [[H. C. Speir]] signed him to a [[recording contract]] with [[Vocalion Records]]. On October 10, 1927, he recorded "[[Jim Jackson's Kansas City Blues]]", which became a best-seller, and in the [[melody]] and [[lyrics]] of which can be traced the outline of many later blues and [[rock and roll]] songs, including "[[Rock Around The Clock]]" and "[[Kansas City (R&B song)|Kansas City]]".  Following his [[hit record|hit]] Jackson recorded a series of 'Kansas City' follow-ups and soundalikes. It also led to other artists covering and reworking the song, including [[Charlie Patton]], who changed it to "Gonna Move To Alabama".<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 121
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Jackson moved to Memphis in 1928, and made a series of further recordings, including the comic medicine show song "I Heard the Voice of a Pork Chop".  He also appeared in [[King Vidor]]'s all-black 1929 [[film]] ''[[Hallelujah! (1929 film)|Hallelujah!]]''.<ref name="amg"/>

Jackson ran the Red Rose Minstrels, a travelling [[medicine show]] which toured Mississippi, [[Arkansas]] and [[Alabama]].  As a talent scout for [[Brunswick Records]], he discovered Rufus "[[Speckled Red]]" Perryman, gaining him his first recording session.<ref name="silvester">Peter J. Silvester, ''A Left Hand Like God : a history of boogie-woogie piano'' (1989), page 112-113.</ref>  Shortly afterwards, in February 1930, Jackson recorded his own last session.  He later moved back to Hernando, and continued to perform until his death in 1937.

[[Janis Joplin]] later recorded a [[cover version|version]]  of "Kansas City Blues", inserting the lines "Babe, I'm leavin', yeah I'm a-leavin' this mornin' / Goin' to Kansas City to bring Jim Jackson home".

Jackson was a major influence on the [[Chicago]] bluesman [[J. B. Lenoir]], and his "Kansas City Blues" was a regular fixture of [[Robert Lee McCollum|Robert Nighthawk]]'s [[concert]] set list.<ref name="amg"/>

The song "Wild About My Lovin'" was covered by [[The Lovin' Spoonful]] and released on their 1967 album, ''[[The Best of The Lovin' Spoonful]]''.
